text: Maiden’s Dream (?): Seeking and Finding
On my bed in the night,
I sought\f + \fr 3:1 \ft Or “I seek” \f* him whom my ⸤heart⸥\f + \fr 3:1 \ft Literally “soul” \f* loves.
I sought him, but I did not find him.
Now I will arise, and I will go about in the city,
in the streets and in the squares;
I will seek him whom my ⸤heart⸥\f + \fr 3:2 \ft Literally “soul” \f* loves.
I sought him, but I did not find him.
The sentinels who go about in the city found me.
“Have you seen the one whom my ⸤heart⸥\f + \fr 3:3 \ft Literally “soul” \f* loves?”
⸤Scarcely had I passed⸥\f + \fr 3:4 \ft Literally “As little that I passed” \f* by them
when I found him whom my ⸤heart⸥\f + \fr 3:4 \ft Literally “soul” \f* loves.
I held him and I would not let him go
until I brought him to the house of my mother,
into the bedroom chamber of she who conceived me.
Adjuration Refrain
I adjure you, ⸤O maidens of Jerusalem⸥,\f + \fr 3:5 \ft Literally “O daughters of Jerusalem” \f*
by the gazelles or by the does of the field,

do not arouse or awaken love until it pleases!\f + \fr 3:5 \ft Or “Do not stir up or awaken the love until it is willing,” or “Do not disturb or interrupt \fq our \ft love-making until it is satisfied” \f*
Royal Wedding Procession
What \add is\add* this coming up from the desert
like a column of smoke,
perfumed with myrrh and frankincense
from all the fragrant powders of the merchant?
Look! \add It is\add* Solomon’s ⸤portable couch⸥!\f + \fr 3:7 \ft Literally “couch” or “portable sedan chair” \f*
Sixty mighty men surround ⸤it⸥,\f + \fr 3:7 \ft Literally “her” \f*
the mighty men of Israel.
All of them ⸤wield swords⸥;\f + \fr 3:8 \ft Literally “holders of sword” \f*
\add they are\add* ⸤trained in warfare⸥,\f + \fr 3:8 \ft Literally “learnt of war” \f*
each with his sword at his thigh
\add to guard\add* ⸤against terror⸥\f + \fr 3:8 \ft Literally “because of the fear” \f* in the night.
⸤King Solomon⸥\f + \fr 3:9 \ft Literally “The king, Solomon” \f* made for himself a sedan chair
from the wood of Lebanon.
He made its column of silver, its back\f + \fr 3:10 \ft Or “its support,” “its base,” “its headrest,” “its litter,” “its cover” \f* of gold, its seat of purple;

its interior is inlaid \add with\add* leather\f + \fr 3:10 \ft Or “love.” The Hebrew term here translated “leather” is spelled the same as the term for “love.” Most likely this is an example of a word play that puns on the intentional ambiguity: “Its interior was inlaid with leather//love by the maidens of Jerusalem” \f* by ⸤the maidens of Jerusalem⸥.\f + \fr 3:10 \ft Literally “by the daughters of Jerusalem” \f*
Come out and look, ⸤O maidens of Zion⸥,\f + \fr 3:11 \ft Literally “O daughters of Zion” \f* at ⸤King Solomon⸥,\f + \fr 3:11 \ft Literally “the king, Solomon” \f*
at the crown with which his mother crowned him
on the day of his wedding,
on the day of the joy of his heart!
